Fields.DialogueText: This tea is delicious.
It's decent enough. A little blander than I'd like, but it's a palate cleanser.
Ceremonial grade matcha is hard to come by out here, Kanchou. At least savor it.
It's certainly kept me awake through these last few films.
Perhaps French cinema isn't your style.
Believe me, I'm trying. I enjoy spending time with you.
And I appreciate it. But we don't have to like the same things.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe I just haven't found the right one.
Maybe we can get some American films on board.
I can't stand watching another French film. I just can't.

Fields.DialogueText: There's a whole world of film out there. Drama, history, romance... maybe mysteries are more your style.
Two of the American girls have recommended King Kong to me now. I'm going to have to see what the fuss is all about.
That's all right. I'm not going to force you. But I insist on the tea. It's good for you.
If we're striking out on film, however, I might invite you to help with the charts. I've had to start from scratch since the Renoir fiasco.
That's got to be frustrating. All that work, disappeared into the waves.
And a con man with it. If I were a stonemason, I'd probably come to terms with stuffing bricks in his trousers and making him swim.
... We might bond over some crime thrillers, come to think of it.
Perhaps not at first, but over time. Just like with the bricks.
*ALARM*
Oh, come, now. What's that look supposed to mean?
Nothing. Just... wondering how many bricks it would take to sink a Morgana.
Enough that I'd rather build a nice cottage or twelve. But I can be convinced otherwise.
@BATTLE
I thought I'd find you with the navigation team today.
They haven't needed my assistance lately. I've been focusing on drawing new charts from scratch.
Back to the drawing board, eh?
Okashī. I believe they phrased it "Make your own if you think you can do better."

Fields.MenuText: Let them work. They know what they're doing.
That's no way to treat their Belle.
Can you do better?

Fields.DialogueText: I know, Kanchou. I can't help looking at some of these charts and knowing they could be more... precise.
Many of my sisters would agree. But I choose to let my work speak for itself.
Kami have better eyesight and finer motor control than humans. Well, broadly speaking. It's difficult for me to do worse, and I mean that in the nicest possible way.
Nothing like a first draft to work the kinks out, right?
That's how I choose to view it. I'm pushing the boundaries of what can be done in this medium.
More mountains?
With finer detail on the trees covering them.
Well, one thing's for sure. We'll have the most colorful charts in the Imperial Navy when you're through. Maybe in the whole Fleet.
And the easiest to read, too! There's a line between colorful and busy, and using clear symbols helps me not to cross it.
While pushing the boundaries.
Have you seen human maps from centuries ago, Kanchou? All those tiny drawings of buildings and flags and people...
Not to mention the occasional sea monster in the margins.
Here there be Funayūrei. The more things change, the more they stay the same.
@BATTLE
Standardization is the way in this modern age, of course. But there was so much more color and artistry when they were still mapping the world. So much more emotion and wonder...
*ALARM*
We've had a letter from Command about the footage we sent them.
They really liked La Marseillaise, huh?
Oh, let's not dance around it. They've got questions about the Morgana footage.
Specifically about how to get more of it.
How'd you guess?

Fields.MenuText: I was hoping to get more of it myself. It could be valuable to the war effort.
I thought of what I'd least like to do and proposed it.
You get this gleam in your eye when you've got an idea.

Fields.DialogueText: Not to mention gripping watching for a movie night.
That kind of resolve will win us the war, Kanchou. Don't be afraid.
That might just be the way my eyes catch the light. They're quite reflective.
Hmm. It says they're sending a camera crew to record us while we fight.
Yatta! It's been so long since we entertained guests.
Especially guests who are who they say they are.
And who have higher callings than personal gain. Imagine what we'll learn from this!
You're a good Belle. The Emperor would be proud.
Anyone in my position would do the same. But I think I'd do the same even if I weren't a Kami.
Not nearly as explosively.
You don't have to blow something up to be heard. But it helps.
*ALARM*
Sugureta! Let's help these Funayūrei slip beneath the waves.
@BATTLE
That chart's looking better and better all the time.
I thought I'd focus on Tokyo Bay today. That is where we're to be meeting the camera crew. It's also home.

Fields.MenuText: You might make two of that chart - one for our use and one to frame.
It's like seeing a familiar street, isn't it?
A dutiful Kami like you doesn't need reminding.

Fields.DialogueText: That's the plan, Kanchou. It's more personal than the Imperial Portrait, anyway. Not to mention better reading.
A street that no human force can alter. Well, unless you're Dutch. Land reclamation is kind of their thing.
Even we succumb to stress and fear from time to time. The memory of gliding into the Uraga Channel's embrace... it is there when my resolve is not.
Your calligraphy's superb. It's... wait, that's not kanji.
Non, ça ne l'est pas.
It's a map of Kanagawa Prefecture... in French?
For practice. I've got to keep the immersion going somehow.
Well, I wouldn't want to look like I'm playing favorites.
Maybe you can rescue one from the sea after the fight. Would that help?
Quelqu'un est un comédien.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Oh, right. Weren't you built there?
By the Uraga Dock Company in Yokosuka. There's nothing quite like the waters of home to remind one of the mission.
I'm sure you can pester some of the crew to help.
How's the French coming along, Kasumi?
Better. One of the French crew recognized what I'd been writing and struck up a conversation.
Oh, let me try it on you! Je suis heureux d'appeler le capitaine un ami et allié.
"I am happy to call the captain a friend and ally." Back at you.
"Le capitaine est un guerrier de gaufre."
Wait... no... I just called you a waffle warrior.
Sometimes that's all it takes.
I'm glad she did. I thought I'd be a little more... oh, I don't know. Unapproachable?

Fields.MenuText: That's probably more to do with you being busy than with you being a Belle. If that's what you're getting at.

Fields.DialogueText: I have been known to work straight through meals. In the middle of the mess. The whole lunch crowd can pass me by if I'm really at it.

Fields.MenuText: Don't you like it that way?
You are one of the most powerful destroyers. You're not to be trifled with.

Fields.DialogueText: The dilemma of the creative. Wanting to share their interests, yet afraid to lose the thread.
I am an Asashio-class. But we don't bite. Indiscriminately.
It's from the heart. That counts for something.
I wonder if the camera crew might not want to capture moments like that?
Like you calling me a waffle warrior?
Well, specifically what that represents. We are living our lives between fighting for them.
Ask them yourself. We're bringing them aboard once this engagement's done.
*ALARM*
Sagami Bay has been under pressure lately. I just hate to keep artists waiting.
The mission comes first.
Try holding a calligraphy pen and waiting for the ship to stop rocking. It sets the poem in your heart to pacing.
@BATTLE
Finally an audience!
This will be simple. It's like they're not even there.
Good artists are unobtrusive, Kanchou. It's easy to change a scene just by observing it.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose cartography is an art too.
I don't know if there are a lot of artists in the IJN.
Just by looking at something?

Fields.DialogueText: And a science. Great minds combine the two.
War is an art too, Kanchou. There's even a book about it.
Drawing enemy fire counts as upsetting the scene. We have a responsibility to them, and they to us.
There is the one wrinkle, of course...
The lead cameraman advised me to keep things... domestic, in terms of language.
Or English, or Dutch. Just while we're being filmed.
Who's we? They're out here to film the Morganas.
They insisted I be featured prominently as well. I suppose it's to get a sense of my technique.
Something wrong?
They don't want you speaking French?
I guess I can't argue with that. It still seems like an odd request. You don't need to know the language to appreciate a visual medium.
Hai. But I suppose it helps... however unnecessary it may seem.
*ALARM*
So we carry on as normal.
In all other ways. Just pretend they're not here.
@BATTLE
Soshite... hyah!
I don't usually see you with your weapons outside of combat.
Ah! Kanchou, yōkoso. You've caught me at the end of the shoot.
I wasn't aware there was one. Well, that there were others.
Spur of the moment. One of the camera crew wanted to get some action shots.

Fields.MenuText: You cut an intimidating figure.
It looks like the Morganas aren't the only shipgirls being studied.
Maybe you could show them your cartography skills.

Fields.DialogueText: Just wait until you see me in full armor!
I'm happy to teach my people more about the Kami. It will be educational and inspiring!
They were less interested in that. Perhaps some candid calligraphy...
Is this a research mission or a fashion show?
I suppose there is no reason it can't be both. It's all in how you frame it.
Hmm. I wonder if any of the other navies are doing something like this.
I'd be surprised if they weren't, Kanchou. Human warfare has come a long way, but the leaders have always wanted to know exactly what was going on. The people, too.
Without having to fight the war themselves to learn it.
History of the world, is it not? You humans seem determined to have your cake and eat it.
For better or for worse.
It's fascinating. There's always a way, Kanchou. It's finding it that's hard.
*ALARM*
Oh! Shoot's over, people! It's time to show you some real action!
@BATTLE
Morning. You know, I don't think I've ever seen you sleep.
All right, I don't think I've ever known you to sleep. Sorry, poor choice of words.
Just having a little fun, Kanchou. Language is tricky that way.

Fields.MenuText: One of these days I'll know what you see in it.
If you're looking for something to do, I'm sure the camera crew are itching for an interview.
You're not feeling under the weather, are you?

Fields.DialogueText: The same words can mean completely opposite things, depending on the inflection, the audience, the context... that doesn't fascinate you?
Ah, well, that's the crux of the matter. I've given them so many already.
Oh, no, not at all. Remember, I enjoy the chill. It's in my name, after all. "Spring Mist..."
No, it's just... with the shoot schedule and all, it's been so long since I had a moment to myself.
I do enjoy your company. Besides, I wanted your opinion on something.
The Funayūrei footage we've shot lately. I think there's value in doing some of our own study.
Like the IJN searching it for insight on the enemy. I'm all for it.
@BATTLE
Good. That wouldn't be proper.
Yawn... Ohayōgozaimasu.
So naturally you tracked me down.
What's that?
Perfect! I'll block out an evening and get some tea together. Perhaps a little kaigun kare from whatever the galley isn't using...
This is an excuse for a movie night, isn't it.
I'm not saying it isn't.
Good. It's been too long.
*ALARM*
Just a little bit longer in the spotlight, Kanchou. We'll make our excuses and win back some time later.
You're always calm. Well, almost always.
Distinction without a difference.
What do you think we'll see that the IJN won't?
I don't know. That's why we're sure to see something.
You're talking in riddles.
An elegant and edifying way of making one's point. We will see something because we're not looking for anything specific.
You think the higher-ups have an ulterior motive.
I love my country, Kanchou. The old men who run it... well, they are old men. They have old ideas masquerading as new ones.
It's just a feeling I have. I've had it since the soft moratorium on Western languages.
That did strike me as weird.
Maybe it's nothing. Maybe their people just like to streamline things. But I'll withhold judgment until we can compare notes.
@BATTLE
That's a lot of calligraphy for a shopping list.
Like it? I thought it might calm me down.

Fields.MenuText: You mean our strategy session.

Fields.DialogueText: I can be rattled on occasion. I thought I still had some matcha left over for our movie night. Imagine my dismay.

Fields.MenuText: I thought I saw some tears in your searchlights.
Shame. I was starting to like that stuff.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! Poetic, Kanchou, but Kami do not work that way. Well, not exactly that way.
Thank goodness. I was beginning to think you'd never give it the respect it deserves.
*ALARM*
Damn. Showtime. What do we have instead of matcha for tonight?
It'll have to be my gyokuro. I just hope I'm in the mood for something grassy...
Thoughts on what?
I thought I'd go a little more adventurous with this chart.

Fields.MenuText: I recognize those gestures.
I'm not seeing the connection.
I thought Okinawa looked a little tea-stained.

Fields.DialogueText: It's lending more and more credence to my theory about Funayūrei practices.
Look closer, Kanchou. Do you recognize the way I've posed the Funayūrei?
Merde! Well, maybe I can turn it into clouds. But look at the Funayūrei I've drawn.
I've definitely seen those gestures before. That one there has a certain sweep of the arm before she goes for a broadside.
Say, I think you're right. They do have certain tells, don't they?
Everyone has habits they fall into when they think no one is looking. Especially those who aren't used to leaving witnesses.
Magnifique!
You're noticeably more French lately.
The filmmakers are leaving soon. They can stand a whiff of the foreign on the way out.
Shall we put your theory to the test?
I'll bet you half a pound of matcha I'm correct!
@BATTLE
Pensées?
"Here there be Funayūrei." Can't go wrong with the classics.
Oui. With a little inspiration from our movie night. See?
This is great! As long as we're watching them, we can predict their actions.
*ALARM*
The ship seems a little emptier now the cameras are gone, doesn't it?
Spatially, yes, but I can't help thinking the opposite. There was a certain... void about their presence.

Fields.MenuText: They're working for the government. It'd be weird if they weren't.
What did they say to you?
They did seem oddly dismissive of our foreign crew.

Fields.DialogueText: The government is not the country. There's a very important difference.
Lots of compliments, mostly. They were quite fawning, if we're being honest.
One of them actually asked me if I could keep the gunnery crews Japanese while they filmed! Of course I drew the line there.
I figured they might spin our mission. Not a whole lot we can do about that, unfortunately.
I'd hate to end up in some sort of propaganda film. The recent laws have practically guaranteed it, should I show up in any of the theaters. Especially in pacified regions of China.
I just hope... well, it's out of our hands for now.
... Kanchou. I suddenly find myself in the mood for a movie. Join me tonight?
Sure. What did you have in mind?
Something from before those laws I mentioned.
*ALARM*
Surprise me. You're good at surprises.
We Kami were a pleasant one!
They're government contractors, not ghosts.
It was the way they spoke to me, Kanchou... the questions they asked. To the extent that they had any, they were especially interested in matters... patriotic.
I'll write to the IJN. They won't release anything without at least running it by us.
@BATTLE
Matcha! I'm as good as my word, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
So what's this one all about?
Kyojinden. The Giant. Mansaku Itami's most recent film... and probably his last, unfortunately. He hasn't been well lately.
So let me get this straight. There's a convict who goes and becomes a mayor, and then he adopts a daughter...
Starting to sound familiar?

Fields.MenuText: Kasumi, this is Les Misérables.
It's on the tip of my tongue...
I'm afraid I'm not as well read as I should be.

Fields.DialogueText: Fu seikaidesu. It is The Giant. It was inspired by Hugo's novel.
Wait until the girl falls in love. That might jog your memory.
Nobody is. That's what makes other people so interesting.
I'm starting to see why you wanted to watch this.
I miss movies like this, Kanchou.
Is that what I think it is?
But you were right about the Morganas and their tells.
Hai. And who better to share my victory with than you?
*ALARM*
Tonight. Let's rack up another one in the meantime.
It's easy to change a scene just by observing it.
Any culture knows the value of hope and redemption. This story works as well for us as it did for the French.
Now it's all public-welfare this and spirit-and-virtues that. I'd hoped we could provide some insight into winning this war without any kind of spin.
Easier still to lie by telling very selective truths.
Let's just enjoy the movie. We can get worked up over their movie once we've seen it.
You're right. Even a smile can be an act of defiance.
What are you looking at?
Look there, Kanchou! We're close to the Chinese coast. You can just see the Matsu Islands over to port.
I'm afraid I can't.
Mochiron. I forget sometimes that Kami eyesight is different from that of a human.

Fields.MenuText: Not all of your sisters feel that way.
Those kinds of distinctions aren't value judgments.
Humans can work around these limitations.

Fields.DialogueText: Not all of my sisters have my patience. One more "difference."
Not inherently. But they're easily recast as such. I just choose to ignore them.
Whatever you need, you build. I like that about you!
Doesn't it excite you to look at the mainland?
Ooh, that's interesting. It would be like someone standing on the moon and looking down on the earth.
We should all try to inspire people to fetch that far.
If they were crazy enough.
It's all the same landmass if you zoom out far enough. Sometimes it takes great efforts to make that clear.
If doing that makes someone crazy... well, the world will catch up. Remember Tadataka and his maps?
*ALARM*
If I get there.
@BATTLE
That's a charitable way of putting it.
If you want to call it that. I don't like thinking in terms of "better" or "worse." Not when we're such different beings.
It's certainly beautiful. And it's kind of neat to stand where the horizon used to be and look back.
That's a little farfetched.
Just think... one could start walking in China and get all the way to France by land!
The ones he spent seventeen years making. How does anyone do that?
Their passion bites them and never lets them go. You'll understand when you get there.
If you don't, then find someone who does. And be ready to be pleasantly surprised.
Buried in charts with the navigation team!
They're really warmed to you.
The navigator I spoke to in the mess put in a good word for me. They know I'm only curious.
Though a little less aggressively so.
Can't strike all the gold yourself.
I can't. But it'd be dereliction itself not to at least try.
That was not one of my favorite battles of late.
It kept us on our toes, but not in the way I'd like. Did you notice anything different about the Funayūrei?

Fields.MenuText: They were spookier than usual.
It was like they were actually trying to win this time.
We could barely keep up with them. It was like fighting them for the first time again.

Fields.DialogueText: At least you're watching them. Though perhaps not closely enough.
That says less about them and more about us, Kanchou.
They're not nearly as predictable as I'd hoped they'd be from here on.
That sweep of the arm that heralded a broadside? Torpedo. And a few other things besides.
I don't think they had to. They're just as capable of self-reflection as we are. And they're constantly evolving. If one pattern doesn't work, they'll process it right out.
Changing something by observing it, eh?
You've been scarce today.
And helpful.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
You think the Morganas knew they were being filmed?
Nevertheless, I'll have to observe them a little more closely next time... after which I'll need plenty of tea.
And maybe a little more Mansaku Itami?
Maybe Jean Renoir.
I don't need to see the bees buzzing among the flowers from on deck to know they're working. But our lives don't depend on that knowledge, do they?

Fields.MenuText: So what do we do now?

Fields.DialogueText: You couldn't see it, Kanchou, but I swear one of those monsters winked at me.
She knew you were observing her?
Funayūrei eyes are just as good as Kami eyes. Better, in some cases.
And they use them to try and rattle you? Shows what they know.
I daresay I used mine more effectively.
Sometimes the most cinematic moments happen when you're nowhere near a camera. Do we have a pirate film on hand?
I could see about getting a reel of The Buccaneer. I'm sure the crew would enjoy it.
You'll convert me to American cinema yet!
What we were doing before. Don't fix what isn't broken.

Fields.MenuText: What a waste of time.
I'm surprised it worked for as long as it did.

Fields.DialogueText: No secret weapon stays secret for long.
Need some binoculars for the fight ahead?
You don't look at the coasts that way?
I might at that, Kanchou. My distance vision is sharp as anything, but I'd still prefer to see it up close.
@BATTLE
Kuso. Just as I thought.
If we knew what would waste our time, we'd never do anything.
Blasted her right off the prow like a figurehead in a pirate film. I wish we'd gotten that on camera!
We need some camera equipment of our own on board.
Making our own movies?

Fields.MenuText: Strange for a Belle not to be patriotic.
Does anyone aboard have any filmmaking experience?
It wouldn't be the strangest request Command has fulfilled.

Fields.DialogueText: Not in the way those fossils in Tokyo would like me to be.
I'm sure we could learn. I've certainly exposed you to enough of the stuff.
I think one of the American girls has a lock on that. Some foolery or other about a trebuchet...
I wonder if we could put something together as comprehensive as Tadataka's atlas.
It's an arms race. They know they're being observed, so...
Kasumi?
They know they're being observed! Kanchou, that footage the General Staff commissioned is worthless!
Those bloody Funayūrei... smiling for the camera all this time.
Because we wrote the script. Once we thought we saw a pattern, we latched onto it like a barnacle.
Shame that work has to end up on the cutting room floor.
It's not the first thing we've been involved in that serves a different purpose than intended. I know it won't be the last.
Our own documentaries, to be specific. Without any of the patriotic license I suspect the General Staff recommended.
On the Morganas? It'd have to be a quarterly journal or something. You've seen how they adapt.
Kasumi, you're right! We have to tell them the arithmetic's changed.
You've got to admit they play their part well.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Here come our stars now.
Package for us, Kanchou.
It's addressed to you.
From the Navy General Staff. That makes it for both our eyes.

Fields.MenuText: It's the footage, isn't it?
Tea for our movie nights?
Can't you handle the bad news yourself once in a while?

Fields.DialogueText: Judging by the weight of the package... I'd say yes. Or twenty-something kilos of matcha.
Don't I wish.
You're the kanchou. That makes everyone's bad news your business.
As expected. It's the rough cut. And there's a letter, of course. Hmm. "... Contribution to Imperial integrity... threats at home and abroad, human and demon..."
Hai. Of course they do. We fell in line. I even paused my French studies for them.
At least they're seeking our seal of approval.
In the form of a rubber stamp, I expect.
*ALARM*
Save it for later, Kasumi. Sometimes these things benefit from being put down for a while.
You're right. I was tempted to put this down in a Funayūrei's teeth.
@BATTLE
Sounds like they appreciate our cooperation.
Think you could make the throw?
With practice. I expect some of those faux-Greek Belles in the Royal Navy would be happy to give pointers.
Isn't international cooperation fun?
That footage... was not as bad it could have been.
I can respect the camera work.
Not to mention the subjects.
Let's not let our bias color our assessment.

Fields.MenuText: You don't think we're photogenic?
Definitely not. Militarily, it's practically useless.
In all other ways, it was exactly what you'd expect from a propaganda film.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I do. But we're not out here to look pretty.
Worse than useless. Deceptive.
And even its value as one of those is debatable.
Would I be remiss in saying the Morganas are too pretty?
Hmm... indelicate, but I see what you're getting at. The way it's cut fails to show the horror of what we face.
*ALARM*
I don't think the General Staff likes being kept waiting.
@BATTLE
Did you see any captured crew aboard them?
I was there for some of that filming. They conveniently cut away before some of those poor people lumbered into view.
Plenty of narration about our crew, though. You catch that one ensign taking a nap?
The British one on his break?
Not to hear the narrator tell it. And intercut with scenes of our Japanese crew in action... I think I can see what the government wants out of this footage.
The industrious, ideal sailors forging on despite the decadence of the Westerners. Invincible and unconquerable.
And waiting for our input.
As you said before, Captain. I'm going to sit on this for a while.
Yoi. I'm not in a mood to respond civilly. Those Funayūrei will serve as proxies.
What's so funny?
Oh, Kanchou, come join us! The crew and I were discussing the General Staff's little film project.

Fields.MenuText: You've certainly warmed to it.
They don't look particularly offended.
You mean that travesty of warfare?

Fields.DialogueText: In a manner of speaking!
Jōdandesho? They loved it!
Oh, lighten up, Kanchou. Now that I've acted out my anger, I think I can laugh at it a little.
I mentioned it to the navigation team, who mentioned it to the radiomen. Soon it was all anyone would ask me about.
It was, at first. But then our sleeping ensign got curious. Next thing I knew, we had a movie night on our hands.
I wish you'd been there, Kanchou. We all got together for a good heckling session.
With sake instead of matcha, I take it.
For those who wanted to partake. Oh! And then around midnight someone had the bright idea of killing the sound and taking turns playing benshi.
You took turns narrating and acting? I would have loved to see that!
Some of these fine folks were better than Renoir! And that snoring sound effect... oh, do it again, do it again!
*ALARM*
Kanpekidesu. Well, it was really funny. Do you think we can get more films like it?
A girl can dream...
@BATTLE
Ha! You could sleep through a battle! No, don't get me wrong, I envy you...
That must have been frustrating.
So that's what all the laughter was last night.
Maybe if we ask the General Staff really politely, they'll even supply us with more sake.
Wire from the General Staff. They're getting impatient.
I suspected they might. I'm acting accordingly.
You're working on a chart of the Yellow Sea.
If you squint, you can just see Qingdao.

Fields.MenuText: These men are going to want answers soon. Even a Belle has to answer to someone.
You certainly paint a pretty picture of the place.
My vision's decent, but not that good.

Fields.DialogueText: That is why I am thankful for you to deflect for me.
That's the easy part. The hard part is choosing what should represent it.
I hear Germany's making strides with contact lenses.
They could use my tastes. Locations... You know, the year before Kyojinden, Itami-sensei worked with that German hack Arnold Fanck.
Daughter of the Samurai, right? I hadn't seen that one.
They called it The New Earth back home. And you're missing precisely nothing.
That bad?
Japanese boy is betrothed to Japanese girl. Japanese boy meets German girl. German girl is a proper Aryan who can't marry the honorary kind.
The General Staff should hire you as a location scout.
Japanese boy saves Japanese girl from suicide by volcano. Then they live happily ever after in Manchukuo. The end.
That sounds remarkably boring.
Morality plays are like that. Keeping your culture to yourself and sticking slavishly to the old ways... it's foolish in a world that's getting smaller every day.
It's definitely what feels safest to a lot of people.
And they're wrong. If there's one thing you humans are good at, it's putting your differences aside to work together. How can anyone preach superiority when it takes all of us to beat the Funayūrei?
Cutting and framing, as we've seen.
Truths half hidden are still lies. When Japan takes her place in the sun, it will be with friends, not subjects.
*ALARM*
We're within view of the Chinese coast. Let's show the Funayūrei what we're willing to do to protect it.
@BATTLE
Navigation duty wasn't enough for you?

Fields.MenuText: It's never been my favorite, but you do pretty well with it.

Fields.DialogueText: Nothing's for everyone. I appreciate you trying.
Consider it a celebration, Kanchou. I've come up with an elegant solution to our problem.
The cooks were delighted to have me help out. Kaigun kare's easy enough to make. Delicious, too.

Fields.MenuText: Mmm. What would it take to get you in here every day?
Any chance of cutting us in on your sake ration?

Fields.DialogueText: Peace and a lack of coasts to map.
I'm generous, not ascetic.
Finally. I was starting to think the admirals would submit a formal complaint to Command.
Which is why I sent them a letter explaining our position just the other day.
Wait, already!?
I thanked them for their diligence in keeping up with the situation and assured them we were hard at work deliberating on how best to assess their national unity film.
By which you meant getting drunk and laughing at it.
The creative process is different for everyone.
I then advised them that we recommended only a single cut, which would arrive with the film via the next postal delivery.
Kasumi, what did you send them?
The best entertainment we've had since Renoir's play-acting. The crew will miss it.
*ALARM*
Mā. I was looking forward to this. Well, it'll simmer for a few hours.
You're enjoying this, aren't you.
Trust me, I'm laughing with you.
@BATTLE
No response yet from the General Staff.
I thought not. They must still be arguing over how to take it.
So you really recommended only a single cut?
I had a ceremonial katana lying around. Gathering dust, mostly.
I sent it with the film reel, inscribed with the word "Lengthwise."

Fields.MenuText: You kept them in suspense for that?
What's stopping them from using it anyway?
You threatened them!?

Fields.DialogueText: The anticipation was even tastier than the kaigun kare.
An excellent question. If I denounced it, the military censor wouldn't print it. But that's the beauty of it: I don't have to.
I threatened their taste in filmmaking. They know the difference.
Of course I also sent them a long letter enumerating my dissatisfaction on strategic, cultural, and aesthetic grounds.
Which is why I also wrote to the director.
I'm surprised you kept up with him.
No...
A letter which will never see the light of day, should they decide to go ahead with it.
Oh, it was a boring correspondence, really. He went on and on about his beach estate on Jeju Island. Amazing what propaganda will buy you.
When the military's footing the bill, money is no object.
I mentioned that, too. It's bought me such powerful guns. With a respectable range, I might add.
All that expense for little old me, with nothing to do between battles but draw painstakingly accurate maps of the Empire's coasts.
I take it he got the message.
He got a message. That's why I never liked propaganda. True art is open to interpretation.
*ALARM*
And he really is an artist at heart. He'll figure it out.
@BATTLE
This is probably the shortest letter we've gotten from the General Staff.
Ooh, what's it say?

Fields.MenuText: That's the understatement of the century.
Looks like they got the message.
What's that supposed to mean?

Fields.DialogueText: The key to wielding power is to say everything while saying nothing.
The IJN respects decisiveness. Our director fears it.
We got our way. That's what matters.
The military censor's got final say about how you Belles are presented. One way or another, the IJN's going to come out on top.
And I hope they do, Kanchou. But we can do it without dancing around what the Funayūrei truly are. We can do it without lying about the people on our side fighting them.
Maybe you'll even get a movie out of it that doesn't need sake to be watchable.
What can I say? It's easy to change a scene just by observing it. Sometimes it's the one way to save it.
As long as it's your story you're saving.
"Careful consideration has deemed the initial vision for which the film was commissioned to be incomplete. A more comprehensive presentation will be necessary."
We do have that right. Now that I've exercised it, perhaps they'll tell our stories a little more honestly.
Just point a camera at you Belles and let it run?
Humans have always wanted front row seats to the war. Why not give them one?
*ALARM*
One of these days we ought to get our own cameras. Times like these, I wish we had some.
And swords to match. Just in case.
@BATTLE
See the paper lately, Kasumi? You're a movie star after all!
"Everyday Life with Ship Girls?" It's so... anodyne.

Fields.MenuText: It's also honest.

Fields.DialogueText: That at least is indisputable. You win wars by deceiving enemies, not allies.
Any chance we'd be getting some of the residuals?
Command actually mentioned this at some point. Belle salaries are paid directly out of those first.

Fields.MenuText: Looks like they just cut together candid footage of you and your sisters.

Fields.DialogueText: Hiryū does have a commanding screen presence. Takao, too. Let's see... Hontōni? They managed to get Shigure in front of a camera? It's worth the price of admission just to see how they managed that.

Fields.MenuText: And wildly popular. Says here it opened at fifty million yen.

Fields.DialogueText: Everyone wants to see the Kami, of course... but making tea? Practicing swordplay? Drawing maps? Humans are so... interesting.
They finally put the footage to use?
No slandering the crew. No outdated battle tips. Just you and your sisters doing what you do best, on the battlefield and off.
So I'm really defraying the Navy's expenses. Well, I do enjoy being helpful.
I guess everybody wins.
Including the director. I sent him some matcha for his trouble. Fear is all well and good for getting your way, but nowhere near incentive enough for people to give it to you.
Strange thing to hear from someone with hobbies like yours.
My hobbies are knowing where people are and how they interact. Is it so strange to want to take something apart to learn how it works?
*ALARM*
Spoken like someone who was built rather than born. I suppose not.
Now, shall we turn that curiosity upon the Funayūrei?
@BATTLE
The Japanese ones. Renoir's not the only one with an impeccable memory.

Fields.MenuText: We're still calling him Renoir, eh?
Do you think you might improve on Tadataka?
The Japanese ones?

Fields.DialogueText: I remember him by his deception. Besides, it tastes better in my mouth than a lot of other things I could call him.
Anyone might, with time and skill enough. That makes him no less monumental a figure.
I was hoping to get started on the Chinese coast, starting from Manchukuo and working down. Japan is more than just the Home Islands, and the world is more than just Japan.
Why do you need the pocket atlas if you've memorized Japan's geography?
People know what paintings look like, but they still go to museums. You have to let yourself be surprised by the genuine article, not just the memory you've fixed in your head.
If you hadn't been born a destroyer, you might have been an excellent surveyor.
I already am. I'm just limited to the coasts. But when I'm done, your coasts will never have to be mapped again!
Well, not in our lifetime. Erosion happens.
Not to mention the occasional crater.
Almost done with your charts?
Never again?
*ALARM*
More work for me, then. I do like to stay busy.
@BATTLE
